docs.lead_paragraph: Donald Kirkendall, an exercise physiologist at the University of North Carolina, will never forget the time he put a heart-rate monitor on a member of the United States rowing team and asked the man to row as hard as he could for six minutes. The standard formula for calculating how fast a human heart can beat calls for subtracting the person's age from 220. The rower was in his mid-20's.
docs.abstract: Formula for calculating maximum heart rate, standard in cardiology and in fitness programs, is being challenged by some physiologists and cardiologists, who say it is simplistic to rely on single formula to predict maximum heart rates of individuals; standard formula involves subtracting person's age from 220; Dr William Haskell, who devised formula in 1970, comment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As with almost all troublesome behaviors that need changing -- be it losing weight, stopping smoking or starting to exercise -- the trick in overcoming alcohol abuse is not so much in the start-up as in the continuation. It sometimes takes years and many failed attempts before a problem drinker can finally achieve lasting sobriety. But the process can be greatly aided and often shortened by tips on coping with life's challenges without resorting to alcohol from people who have overcome serious drinking problems. In her newly published book, ''Sober for Good'' (Houghton-Mifflin, $25), Anne M. Fletcher describes what many of the 222 former abusive drinkers she calls ''masters'' have learned about dealing with the sturm und drang of life without using alcohol to smooth the way.

headline.main: 'Masters' Show How to Get High on Life Without Abusing Alcohol

docs.lead_paragraph: While too much of some kinds of fat is bad for human health, another type of fat called omega-3 is not only benign, but is emerging as essential to good health for a number of different reasons. It is found in its highest concentrations in fish, especially oily fish like tuna and salmon. Research in a number of disciplines shows that lack of omega-3 may play a role in a number of modern maladies, including depression, heart arrhythmia, irritable bowel syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis.

headline.main: Research Suggests Positive Effects From Living Off the Fat of the Sea

docs.lead_paragraph: There may be more to light therapy than meets the eye. For years, doctors have known that exposing people to therapeutic light can help those who suffer from seasonal affective disorder, those winter blues that set in when the days are shorter. The therapy can also help regulate the body's sleeping and waking schedule.

headline.main: Of Light, Tissue and Better Moods

docs.lead_paragraph: In a report with implications for commercial woodworkers as well as people who do repairs at home, federal health officials say they have found evidence that significant amounts of lead may remain in a piece of wood even after a solvent has removed lead-based paint. If the wood is disturbed, for example through sanding, the lead can then be released, exposing people nearby to potentially serious health risks, the officials said, adding that the risk to children was especially great.

headline.main: When Lead Paint Vanishes and Returns

docs.lead_paragraph: If you just cannot get a certain song out of your head, it may not be because the tune is particularly catchy. It could be a brain aneurysm. That is extremely unlikely, of course. But an article in a recent issue of The Mayo Clinic Proceedings describes the case of a 61-year-old woman whose musical hallucinations were caused by two small aneurysms, which occur when the wall of a blood vessel weakens and then swells.

headline.main: A Song in Your Head Can Turn Deadly
